author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Adi Godrej hopes for strong statement on GST in budget
description: Industrialist Adi Godrej is expecting a pro-growth budget. He said that the revenues have increased despite the stimulus and even with the stimulus, the fiscal deficit is lower than the budget target.
tags: Adi Godrej, Budget, Budget 2010-11, Budget 2011, Budget 2011 expectations, Budget 2011 Highlights, Budget 2011 in India, Budget 2011 Income Tax, Budget 2011 India, Budget 2011 service tax, Budget News, Business, Commerce Minister, DTC, FM presents Budget, GDP, GST, Indian Union Budget, Pranab Mukherjee, Rahul Khullar, Reliance BP deal, Union Budget
articleBody: As Pranab Mukherjee rises to present the union budget in a&amp;nbsp;couple of&amp;nbsp;days from now, most people are expecting it to be wish-fulfilling. No matter what, budget is looked upon as a positive stimulus that can help replace the negative sentiment and cheer up the financial markets reasonably.&amp;nbsp;  Industrialist Adi Godrej is expecting a pro-growth budget. He said that&amp;nbsp;the revenues have increased despite the stimulus and even with the stimulus, the fiscal deficit is lower than the budget target. Moreover, he feels that the lower tax rates are increasing collections. In his opinion, if the Reliance Industries-BP oil and gas deal gets quick approval, it can boost FDI inflows even in this fiscal year.  He seems to be suitably impressed by the GDP target figure mentioned in the Economic Survey.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Oil min for quick decision on Cairn-Vedanta deal
description: India's oil ministry wants the cabinet to decide on a deal for Cairn Energy to sell control of its Indian assets to Vedanta Resources as quickly as possible, Petroleum Minister S Jaipal Reddy said on Friday.
tags: Business, Cairn Energy, EGoM, S Jaipal Reddy, Vedanta Resources
articleBody: India's oil ministry wants the cabinet to decide on a deal for Cairn Energy to sell control of its Indian assets to Vedanta Resources as quickly as possible,&amp;nbsp;Petroleum Minister&amp;nbsp;S Jaipal Reddy&amp;nbsp;said on Friday. He said the ministry has floated a cabinet note on the Cairn Vedanta deal and the idea is to take the note as soon as possible. He said officers from the ministry are following it up with key ministries like Finance, Corporate Affairs and the Law ministry. He also said he would like any decision by companies on petrol prices hike to be taken after a meeting of a panel of ministers on fuel prices. On the volatile crude prices, he said an EGoM would likely be called and it would be advisable&amp;nbsp;for oil marketing companies to wait for the EGoM's decision before hiking fuel prices. Commenting on Reliance's USD 7.2 billion deal with BP, Reddy said that he has received a formal request from RIL on the deal. He was quick to add that the RIL-BP deal and the Cairn-Vedanta deal should not be contrasted and compared. Meanwhile, the Petroleum Secretary has said that there is no change in the government's policy on deregulation of petrol prices and OMCs continue to have freedom to determine petrol prices.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: EIH settles insurance claims; 1-time loss of Rs 30.28 crore
description: Hotels operator EIH, which runs Oberoi and Trident chains, said late on Thursday it would report a one-time loss of Rs 3027.9 crore in Jan-March on settlement of insurance claims.
tags: Business, EIH, Hotels operator, Oberoi, Trident
articleBody: Hotels operator EIH, which runs Oberoi and Trident chains, said late on Thursday it would report a one-time loss of Rs 3027.9&amp;nbsp;crore in January-March on settlement of insurance claims. The company had recognised income worth Rs 96.76&amp;nbsp;crore and Rs 52.676 crore on account of insurance claims against losses due to business interruptions in FY09 and FY10, it said in a statement. Against these claims, the insurance company has settled an amount of Rs 112 crore&amp;nbsp;on February 22, leading to a shortfall of Rs 36.984 crore, which would be counted as loss in March quarter, it added. It also said, the insurance company has also settled a claim related to damages to property worth Rs 17.422&amp;nbsp;crore resulting in a surplus of Rs 6.705 crore, which would be counted as income in the March quarter. Reliance Industries, controlled by billionaire Mukesh Ambani, has 14.8% in the hotel chain.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: BP sees over 15 tcf gas resources in RIL blocks
description: BP PLC estimates there are 15 trillion cubic feet (tcf) of gas resources in the 23 blocks it has bought into in its USD 7.2 billion deal with Reliance Industries and there could be more, the company's India head said.
tags: BP plc, Business, Cairn India, Reliance Industries, Sashi Mukundan, Vedanta Resources
articleBody: BP PLC estimates there are 15 trillion cubic feet (tcf) of gas resources in the 23 blocks it has bought into in its USD 7.2 billion deal with Reliance Industries and there could be more, the company's India head said.  Sashi Mukundan told Reuters gas prices in the Indian market had the potential to rise and, if necessary, the two companies would build a terminal to import liquefied natural gas (LNG) to take advantage of an increasing appetite for market-priced gas. &quot;BP's estimate today is that (the 23 blocks) have 15 tcf gas resources ... there is a much larger running room and our coming into this (shows) we believe that we can jointly significantly improve the production,&quot; he said in an interview on Thursday. Reliance's D6 block in the Krishna Godavari basin off the east coast is India's biggest gas producer, but output has slipped on technical problems to about 52 million cubic metres a day (mcmd) from 60 mcmd in 2010 and short of a target 80 mcmd. Mukundan was speaking to Reuters a day after arriving back from Britain where the companies signed the deal -- the biggest foreign direct investment in India's exploration sector. The Indian partnership marks the second major deal under BP's new chief executive Bob Dudley, who last month agreed a share swap with Russia's state-controlled Rosneft to jointly explore the Arctic for offshore oil and gas. It is BP's biggest investment in exploration and production space in Asia and plants it firmly in the fourth of the emerging BRIC economies along with operations in Brazil and China, after it picked up little in Indian government licensing rounds. &quot;We missed the boat until NELP V,&quot; Mukundan said, adding that in 1999, when India launched its New Exploration Licensing Policy (NELP), gas prices were too low and the potential of the country was not widely known. Cairn Energy, which picked up blocks in India before the launch of NELP, is currently trying to sell a majority stake in its Indian arm Cairn India to Vedanta Resources but is bogged down in a royalty dispute with its Indian partner.  Hindu wedding BP has no current plans to buy into Reliance's coal-bed methane blocks, Mukundan added. &quot;We have seen good shows in Mahanadi, Krishna Godavari and we have seen some shows in Cauvery, which we now look to build upon ... there is a potential for us to significantly grow,&quot; he said. Mukundan said the deal was exclusive to both the companies and they could jointly look at further alliances. &quot;This is a Hindu wedding. This will last forever. That's the plan,&quot; he said, when asked about the duration of the tie-up. The equal joint venture between the two companies for marketing and sourcing of gas should be operational in three to six months, Mukundan said, to meet growing demand in the world's second-fastest growing major economy. &quot;The (gas pricing) trend is upward ... the market has appetite for higher priced gas,&quot; he said. &quot;Latent demand is being fully utilised and ... new demand will be created on market fundamentals. It's not going to be based on subsidy regime.&quot; India approves the gas sales pricing formula from more recent fields while older fields awarded to state-run firms have a subsidised price of USD 4.2/million British thermal unit (mbtu). Mukundan said that 25-30% of India's gas consumption is met by imported liquefied natural gas (LNG) which is sold at a much higher price and added that the government could agree higher prices for future field developments. &quot;The government is flexible to look at each of the blocks on its own merit. There is a discussion that some of the more difficult blocks will probably end up with higher pricing.&quot; He said the joint venture could build an LNG terminal and pipelines if it could not find capacity at India's existing facilities. &quot;If we can't get it and we still need to get it, we'll look at the possibility of building our own terminal if needed.&quot;

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: S&amp;P revises RIL outlook to positive
description: Standard &amp; Poor's Ratings Services revised its outlook on India-based Reliance Industries Ltd. (RIL) to positive from stable.
tags: Business, Reliance Industries, RIL, Standard & Poor's Ratings Services
articleBody: Standard &amp;amp; Poor's Ratings Services revised its outlook on India-based Reliance Industries (RIL) to positive from stable. At the same time, we affirmed the 'BBB' long-term corporate credit rating on RIL and the 'BBB' issue rating on the company's senior unsecured notes. We revised the outlook to positive to reflect our expectation that RIL's financial profile would improve and that the company's exposure to India's country risk would reduce after its proposed partnership with BP PLC (A/Negative/A-1). RIL plans to sell 30% of its stake in 23 oil and gas production sharing contracts in India, including KG-D6, to BP for USD 7.2 billion in cash. The company will receive the amount over the next 10-12 months, subject to necessary regulatory approvals. The transaction would significantly improve its liquidity position, resulting in lower debt (after adjusting for cash and cash equivalents of more than USD 1.5 billion). Lower debt, in turn, would improve RIL's ratio of adjusted debt to EBITDA to less than 0.5x for the fiscal year ending March 31, 2012. We also expect BP's significant experience and capabilities of managing deepwater exploration and development operations to help RIL improve its exploration and production (E&amp;amp;P) business in India. The operating performance of RIL's E&amp;amp;P business had weakened in the past two quarters. &quot;The outlook revision also reflects our expectation that RIL will begin to generate positive free operating cash flows (FOCF); the company has had negative FOCF for the past five years,&quot; said Standard &amp;amp; Poor's credit analyst Mehul Sukkawala. &quot;This is because funds from operations have increased to about USD 6 billion to USD 6.5 billion whereas capital expenditure is expected to be about USD 5 billion annually. The improvement in cash flows is on account of the improvement in RIL's operating performance.&quot; RIL's liquidity is strong with cash and cash equivalents of USD 7.1 billion as at December 31, 2010. This is more than enough to cover long-term debt maturities of about Rs 5,000 crore due in one year and short-term debt of&amp;nbsp; Rs 14,900 crore on as at December 31, 2010. RIL's liquidity position would further strengthen after it receives the cash consideration from BP. The company also has unused working capital credit facilities of about INR300 billion, good access to financial markets, and treasury stocks of about US&amp;#36;6.5 billion. We believe that the sale of treasury stocks is a quicker way to raise funds than selling fresh equity. Large cash flows from operations further support RIL's liquidity position, as these are sufficient to meet the company's capital expenditure requirements. The positive outlook reflects our expectation that RIL's financial profile would improve after the proposed partnership with BP. It also reflects our view that the company's operating performance will improve and that the proposed partnership will preserve its competitive position in the E&amp;amp;P business. We could raise the rating if we believe RIL's management is less aggressive in its growth plans and we expect that the company will maintain a modest financial profile by: (1) consistently generating positive FOCF; and (2) maintaining a conservative financial policy with a ratio of adjusted debt to EBITDA at less than 1x. We could revise the outlook to stable if RIL shifts back to an aggressive growth strategy, resulting in a higher-than-expected capital expenditure or the company makes a large acquisition that drains its liquidity or increases its debt. The outlook could also be revised to stable if: (1) RIL makes a large investment in a regulated business in India, such as power; (2) the proposed partnership with BP does not materialize; or (3) we lower India's transfer and convertibility assessment to 'BBB' from 'BBB+'.

headline: CLSA upgrades Reliance to buy after BP deal
description: Brokerage CLSA raised its rating on Reliance Industries to &quot;buy&quot; from &quot;outperform&quot; late on Monday.
articleBody: Brokerage CLSA raised its rating on Reliance Industries to &quot;buy&quot; from &quot;outperform&quot; late on Monday. Late on Monday, BP agreed to invest USD 7.2 billion in the Indian firm to explore for deepwater oil and gas. &quot;There remain several uncertainties -- the value of the deal, payment schedules and the impact on EPS -- but it nonetheless sets a medium term benchmark for Reliance's E&amp;amp;P value,&quot; analysts Somshankar Sinha and Vikash Kumar Jain said in a note. At 9:37 am (0407 GMT) shares in Reliance were up 4.1%, while the main stock index dropped 0.9%.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: RBS ups Reliance Industries share target
description: British bank RBS said it had raised the target price on Reliance Industries to Rs 966 from 900, based on the higher value of the Indian energy major's exploration and production assets following a deal with BP.
tags: BP tie-up, Business, RBS, Reliance Industries
articleBody: British bank RBS said it had raised the target price on Reliance Industries to Rs 966 from 900, based on the higher value of the Indian energy major's exploration and production assets following a deal with BP. &quot;The BP tie-up should help resolve production issues at KG-D6, but commercial issues in terms of gas pricing will still need to be resolved,&quot; RBS said in a note issued late on Monday, while maintaining a hold rating on the stock. Late on Monday, BP agreed to invest USD 7.2 billion in the Indian firm to explore for deepwater oil and gas.  On Monday, shares in Reliance closed 2% higher at Rs 956.5, while the main stock index gained 1.3%.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Major FDI deals in India
description: BP Plc is making one of the biggest foreign direct investments in India, with a USD 7.2 billion tie-up with Reliance Industries to explore for deepwater oil and gas
tags: BP plc, Business, Foreign Direct Investments, Reliance Industries
articleBody: BP Plc is making one of the biggest foreign direct investments in India, with a USD 7.2 billion tie-up with Reliance Industries to explore for deepwater oil and gas.  BP will take a 30% stake in 23 oil and gas blocks and form a 50:50 joint venture with Reliance for the sourcing and marketing of gas, the companies said on Monday. The companies said the future performance payments and the combined investment could amount to USD 20 billion in total. India, one of the world's fastest growing major economies, needs foreign capital to boost infrastructure and sustain economic growth at its near-double-digit targets. Regulatory uncertainty and bureaucratic hurdles, however, have contributed to a slowdown in inbound investment. In the fiscal year that ends in March, India is on track to bring in USD 27.6 billion in FDI inflows, down from USD 35.6 billion in the previous year, a senior official said on Monday. Below are some facts about major foreign investments in India: India's environment ministry last month approved plans by South Korea's POSCO to build a USD 12 billion steel mill, a boost for the foreign investment climate in Asia's third-largest economy after several setbacks for big ticket industrial projects. Vodafone entered India in 2007, paying USD 11.1 billion to buy a 67% controlling stake in Hutchison Whampoa's mobile business in India, in which India's Essar Group is a partner. The deal is the largest inbound foreign direct investment to be completed. Miner Vedanta Resources' planned deal worth up to USD 9.6 billion for control of energy firm Cairn India, slowed by disagreement over royalties, will be decided by India's cabinet, which could delay it further. Japanese drug maker Daiichi Sankyo paid up to USD 4.6 billion in 2008 for control of India's Ranbaxy Laboratories. NTT DoCoMo Inc agreed to pay USD 2.7 billion in 2008 for a 26% stake in Indian telecoms firm Tata Teleservices, giving Japan's top mobile operator a foothold in the world's fastest-growing major mobile market.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Maha Mumbai SEZ can seek formal nod: Comm Min
description: Maharashtra government has indicated to scrap the Reliance-led Maha Mumbai Special Economic Zone (SEZ) in Raigad district stating that the project has not yet taken formal approval, which will be given only when the land is possessed, reports CNBC TV 18 quoting Commerce Ministry’s sources.
tags: Business, Commerce Ministry, Gujarat Positra, Maha Mumbai SEZ, Maha Mumbai Special Economic Zone, Maharashtra Government, Raigadh farmers, Reliance

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Reliance-BP deal not on same footing as Cairn-Vedanta deal
description: UK energy giant BP Plc buying 30% interest in Reliance Industries' 23 blocks including the crown jewel KG-D6 will need government approval to consummate the deal but the transaction is not on the same footing as the Vedanta Resources buying out Cairn India.
tags: BP plc, Business, Cairn, KG-D6, Reliance Industries, UK energy, Vedanta Resources
articleBody: UK energy giant BP Plc buying 30% interest in Reliance Industries' 23 blocks including the crown jewel KG-D6 will need government approval to consummate the deal but the transaction is not on the same footing as the Vedanta Resources buying out Cairn India. BP is buying 30% stake in its 23 out of 29 exploration blocks held by Reliance, for USD 7.2 billion. The transaction, which BP and Reliance said will be &quot;subject to Indian regulatory approvals and other customary conditions,&quot; is nothing but farm-out of interest. Reliance Chairman Mukesh Ambani said the deal is &quot;of course subject to necessary government approval&quot;. &quot;All blocks (in the deal) are under NELP which has a well laid down framework for government approval. We will apply and get approval,&quot; he told reporters in London. Farm-out of interest under New Exploration Licensing Policy (NELP), the regime under which Reliance won the 23 blocks, is allowed and company farming out (or in simple terms selling out) interest is required to make an application to the regulator Directorate General of Hydrocarbons (DGH). Oil Secretary S Sundareshan today said Reliance''s farm- out of stake in the NELP blocks will need government approval. However the nature of the approval will be different from Vedanta Resources'' USD 9.6 billion acquisition of Cairn India as the deal announced today is not transfer of control. In Cairn-Vedanta deal, Cairn Energy Plc of UK is transferring control of its Indian unit to the London-listed mining group, which has no prior experience in oil and gas. The BP-Reliance deal is similar to what Cairn India had done way back in 2004 with ONGC when it farmed-out 90% of its interest and operatorship in gas discovery block of KG-DWN-98/2 which sits next to Reliance''s prolific KG-D6 fields off the Andhra coast. Cairn-ONGC applied and DGH and oil ministry approved it. Unlike the 2004 deal, Reliance is not transferring control or operatorship of the blocks to BP. Reliance said it will retain operatorship of all the 23 blocks including the KG-D6. Also, the major difference lies in the fact that Cairn has itself claimed that its deal with Vedanta is a corporate transaction and not a transfer of stake in the blocks. The corporate transaction, it stated, did not require the permission of government but reluctantly agreed to it. It made conditional application for approval on November 23, more than three months after the deal with Vedanta was announced. The application did not recognise the rights of partner ONGC. With ONGC asserting its rights as well as seeking resolution to the royalty it pays on behalf of Cairn India, Oil Minister S Jaipal Reddy is referring the deal to the Cabinet for approval.

headline: RIL, BP JV for sourcing and marketing of gas in India
description: Reliance Industries have approved strategic partnership with BP for sourcing and marketing of gas in India.

articleBody: Reliance Industries Ltd has informed BSE that the Directors have approved a strategic partnership with BP. This partnership involves formation of a 50:50 joint venture for sourcing and marketing of gas in India and BP taking a 30% stake in 23 oil and gas production sharing contracts that Reliance operates in India. In this regard, the Company has issued a Media Release dated February 21, 2011 titled &quot;BP and Reliance Industries announces Transformational Partnership in India.&quot;  Source : BSE&amp;nbsp;

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Credit Suisse cuts Reliance Industries EPS estimates
description: Credit Suisse said on Friday it had cut its earnings per share estimates for Indian energy major Reliance Industries for fiscal years 2012 and 2013 by 10% and 12% respectively.
tags: Business, Credit Suisse, earnings per share estimates, Reliance Industries
articleBody: Credit Suisse said on Friday it had cut its earnings per share estimates for Indian energy major Reliance Industries for fiscal years 2012 and 2013 by 10% and 12% respectively. It also lowered its target price for Reliance to Rs 1,132 from Rs 1,181 earlier. &quot;Volume growth expectations at D6 oil/gas form a large part of RIL's near-term EPS growth,&quot; analysts Sanjay Mookim and Saurabh Mishra said in a note. &quot;Recent declines, and a lack of company commentary/guidance has introduced risks to this growth,&quot; they wrote. At 9:28 a.m. (0358 GMT), shares in Reliance were trading 0.8% higher at Rs 961.20, while the main stock index was up 0.7%.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: RIL set to roll-out &amp;#36;30 bn mega capex plan
description: Reliance Industries is all set to initiate phase two of its mega capex plan that will take earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) to USD 15 billion by 2015 from USD 8-8.5 billion, reports CNBC-TV18’s Sajeet Manghat.
tags: Business, mega capex plan, Reliance Industries
articleBody: Reliance Industries is all set to initiate phase two of its mega capex plan that will take earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) to USD 15 billion by 2015 from USD 8-8.5 billion, reports CNBC-TV18. Towards achieving this goal, the company has indicated capex plans of USD 25-30 billion dollars over the next five years.  Of this, it will invest USD 10-12 billion in petrochemicals, and USD 10-15 billion on exploration and development of oil &amp;amp; gas discoveries in India and US shale gas. It will invest USD 4.5-4.7 billion in telecom, where it has already pumped in USD 2.8 billion on 4G license and spectrum. Of its USD 15 billion earnings target, it expects USD 5 billion to come from just the refining segment, and a normalized double digit gross refining margin (GRM). Source: CNBC-TV18

headline: BP in talks to buy stake in RIL gas block: Report
description: BP Plc  is in talks with Indian energy major Reliance Industries to buy a 30% to 45% stake in the D6 hydrocarbon block in a basin off India's east coast, the Mint newspaper reported on Monday citing a person with knowledge of the development.
tags: BP plc, Business, D6 hydrocarbon block, Reliance Industries
articleBody: BP Plc&amp;nbsp; is in talks with Indian energy major Reliance Industries Ltd (RIL)&amp;nbsp;to buy a 30% to 45% stake in the D6 hydrocarbon block in a basin off India's east coast, the Mint newspaper reported on Monday citing a person with knowledge of the development. Reliance is pumping 52-53 million cubic metres of gas a day from the Krishna Godavari block, less than the 60 million cubic metres it produced last year, but the country's upstream regulator has said output could rise by April. Officials at Reliance and BP could not immediately be reached for a comment.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Reliance Industries hires advisors to explore Atlas options
description: India's Reliance Industries might challenge Chevron's bid for Atlas Energy, according to a letter disclosed by the US natural gas producer in a filing with the regulators.
tags: Atlas Energy, Business, Chevron, India, Reliance Industries, US natural gas
articleBody: India's Reliance Industries might challenge Chevron's bid for Atlas Energy, according to a letter disclosed by the US natural gas producer in a filing with the regulators. &quot;We believe Reliance, as Atlas Energy's joint venture partner and a company with substantial financial resources, would have been the most natural and obvious potential transaction partner for Atlas Energy,&quot; the Reliance letter said. In April last year, Reliance agreed to pay USD 1.7 billion to Atlas to form a joint venture and own a 40% stake in Atlas' Marcellus Shale operations in the eastern United States.  In November, Chevron announced plans to buy Atlas for USD 3.2 billion.  Reliance said in the letter that Atlas filed with the US Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday it would like to evaluate options including whether it could be able to &quot;create incremental value&quot; for Atlas. The Reliance letter said at no time during the seven months of Atlas' discussions with Chevron, Atlas reached out to the Indian company to gauge its interest in a &quot;possible company-level transaction.&quot; The energy major, controlled by Mukesh Ambani,the world's fourth-richest man with a fortune of USD 29 billion according to Forbes magazine, said it had hired Perella Weinberg Partners and Kirkland &amp;amp; Ellis to evaluate its options. &quot;We were very surprised by the announcement of your deal to be acquired by Chevron,&quot; Reliance told Atlas in the letter. Reliance said during its joint venture negotiations with Atlas it was assured that the Indian company would be the &quot;preferred partner&quot; should Atlas choose to pursue a whole-company transaction. A Reliance spokesman in India declined to comment on the development when reached by Reuters on Thursday. The letter also said Chevron's deal valued Atlas' Marcelus assets at a significant discount to the value attributed to them in the joint venture with Reliance. Reliance has been investing in new areas such as shale gas as it seeks a foothold overseas and seeks to expand its businesses beyond petrochemicals, refining, oil and gas exploration, and retail.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: RIL to shut Jamnagar refinery for 5 weeks
description: Reliance Industies (RIL) is planning to shutdown its Jamnagar Refinery. The five-week shutdown Fluidised Catalytic Cracking Unit (FCCU) of DTA Refinery will be for maintenance and inspection (M&amp;I) purpose.
articleBody: Reliance Industies (RIL) is planning to shutdown its Jamnagar refinery temporarily. The five-week shutdown Fluidised Catalytic Cracking Unit (FCCU) of DTA Refinery will be for maintenance and inspection (M&amp;amp;I) purpose. This M&amp;amp;I shutdown is being planned after five years of sustained operation of the FCCU, the company said. Both the refineries at Jamnagar Complex are planned to operate at maximum crude processing capacity which is. 1.3 Million barrels per day during this period.  All other major secondary processing units at Jamnagar Complex are also planned to operate at normal capacity, including FCCU of SEZ Refinery. For more details, click here &amp;nbsp;

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: RIL to evaluate options in Atlas JV post Chevron buy
description: Reliance has written to Atlas Energy expressing displeasure over the Chevron deal. They say that they should have been given a chance to top Chevron's offer for Atlas energy, since they would have been the most natural and obvious potential transaction partner for Atlas.
tags: Atlas Energy, Business, Chevron, Reliance, shale gas
articleBody: Reliance has written to Atlas Energy expressing displeasure over the Chevron deal. They say that they should have been given a chance to top Chevron's offer for Atlas energy, since they would have been the most natural and obvious potential transaction partner for Atlas.  Reliance says they are upset that at no point in the last seven months has Atlas reached out to them to gauge their interest in this possible company level transaction.&amp;nbsp;  Reliance bought a stake in Atlas's assets in Marcellus Shale, according to the filing, about three months after Reliance and Atlas created the joint venture, Jefferies &amp;amp; Co advised the managements of Chevron and Atlas on a potential acquisition.  Apparently Jefferies has advised Atlas that Reliance may not be interested in acquiring the company post Atlas and other Shale Gas joint venture. Reliance has now questioned why Atlas relied on Jefferies advice for Chevron.  Reliance says that they would like to evaluate all options including their role in the Atlas joint venture and evaluate whether the JV could bring higher value for Atlas Relaiance has substantial financial resources and is the most natural and obvious potential transaction partner for Atlas.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'Rakesh Patil'}
headline: Short RIL on upside: Kedia
description: Short RIL on upside, says Sushil Kedia, FRM, CAIA, CMT, President, ATMA.
tags: ATMA, CAIA, CMT, FRM, President, Reliance Industries, RIL, Stocks Views, Sushil Kedia
articleBody: Short Reliance Industries (RIL) on upside, says Sushil Kedia, FRM, CAIA, CMT, President, ATMA. Kedia told CNBC-TV18, &quot;Reliance has consolidated, so to say after that big explosion upwards at the last Central Government elections and has been since then in a very wide consolidation range that has been compressing. It has now broken downwards under that range of almost 18 months. So that is a very significant thing that with such a large time span of consolidation there is a downward breakdown - keeping that in the mind is the back drop for the next month or two perhaps or Rs 200 on Reliance whichever.&quot; He further added, &quot;In the very short run it oversold, it can make a rebound of Rs 20-30-40 that is a side but those rebounds because of this breakdown from this large consolidation will be opportunities to go short on the stock rather than buy and given Reliance is most important stock in terms of its weightage on the index that is also going to keep the whole market topsy-turvy and the picture of next 15-20 days would be at best range trading and selling on rallies.&quot;

And on the ENP side definitely there have been some negatives coming in. However, over the longer term we don

articleBody: The flagship company of Reliance Group, Reliance Industries (RIL) is set to announce its results for the quarter ended December 2010. According to CNBC-TV18 estimates, its net profit is expected to go up by 29.7% to Rs 5,200 crore in Q3FY11 as against Rs 4,008 crore in same quarter of previous financial year and seen up by 5.6% from Rs 4,923 crore in previous quarter.&amp;nbsp;Sales are seen going up by 9.9% to Rs 62,500 crore from Rs 56,856 crore on year-on-year basis and seen up by 8.7% from Rs 57,479 crore on quarter-on-quarter basis. Operating profit margin is also seen improving at 15.85% versus 13.8% (YoY) but seen declining versus 16.35% (YoY). Factors to watch * Strength in refining &amp;amp; petchem to offset lower E&amp;amp;P EBIT * GRM

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Stable outlook for Indian oil and gas sector in 2011: Fitch
description: Fitch Ratings said, in a just published report, that the outlook for India's oil and gas industry is stable for 2011. This is based on the agency's expectation that ties between the government and its majority-owned oil companies will not weaken.
tags: Business, crude oil prices, Fitch Ratings, India, oil and gas industry
articleBody: Fitch Ratings said, in a just published report, that the outlook for India's oil and gas industry is stable for 2011. This is based on the agency's expectation that ties between the government and its majority-owned oil companies will not weaken. India's state-owned oil companies dominate the sector, and Fitch links their ratings with that of the sovereign because of the sector's strategic importance and the evidence of tangible financial support. Consequently, these companies' stable outlooks reflect that of the sovereign. &quot;Unless crude oil prices rise significantly, the market-linked petrol pricing regime that was implemented in 2010 will continue to operate in 2011. However, the agency does not expect diesel price reform in 2011 as the fuel has a higher impact on reported inflation, which is one of the government's key economic concerns,&quot; says Abhinav Goel, Senior Director in Fitch's corporates team.  The government marginally increased the prices of cooking fuels -- liquefied petroleum gas (LPG, domestic use) and kerosene (public distribution system) in 2010. However, these continue to be subsidised, and Fitch believes that these will remain at levels set by policy requirements, rather than at market prices even in 2011. Consequently, under-recoveries -- which result when tariffs are insufficient to cover costs -- will remain high for these fuels. &quot;The revision in the Outlook for the downstream public sector to Stable from Negative in June 2010 was based on Fitch's expectation that the government will continue to maintain the oil sector reforms introduced in 2010, and support these companies given their role as the government's extended arm for policy implementation,&quot;&amp;nbsp;Goel added. Fitch notes that India's surplus in refining capacity will continue with the commissioning of new facilities in 2011 and beyond. However, public sector refiners are partially protected by price controls. Private sector company, Reliance Industries (Reliance, 'BBB'/Stable), has significant export revenues, benefiting from more complex refineries than most international competitors.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Reliance Industries D6 block capacity falls to 52-53 mmscmd
description: Reliance Industries has a current gas output capacity of 52-53 mn metric standard cubic metres a day (mmscmd) at its D6 block in Krishna-Godavari basin, head of India's upstream regulator said, lower than 60 mmscmd seen in last October.
tags: Business, D6 block, India's upstream regulator, Krishna-Godavari basin, Reliance Industries
articleBody: Reliance Industries has a current gas output capacity of 52-53 mn metric standard cubic metres a day (mmscmd) at its D6 block in Krishna-Godavari basin, head of India's upstream regulator said, lower than 60 mmscmd seen in last October. &quot;Oil and gas fields go through ups and down,&quot; SK Srivastva told reporters on Tuesday, when asked whether gas production at the D6 block has dropped. &quot;In the life of a field such things happen.&quot; Reliance owns 90% in the D6 block, off India's east coast, while Canada's Niko Resources holds the remainder. Srivastva said 22 wells will be operational in the gas block by April, up from the current 18, raising the output capacity to 60 mmscmd when the 2011/12 financial year begins. It could likely touch 80 mmscmd by 2012/13, he added. The upstream regulator is believed to have asked Reliance, which began pumping gas from the D6 block in April 2009, to step up its output, as part of the estimated field development plan. Reliance is expected to pump natural gas at full capacity from its deep-sea field during the year to March 2013, after a delay of almost two years.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: RIL commissions biz transformation plans for FY12: sources
description: Reliance Industries (RIL) has commissioned business transformation plans for FY12, reports CNBC-TV18 quoting sources.
tags: BP, Business, E&P, exploration, Jamnagar, oil, RIL
articleBody: Reliance Industries (RIL) has commissioned business transformation plans for FY12, reports CNBC-TV18 quoting sources. It is learnt that RIL has mandated ATKearney and Booz &amp;amp; Co for business transformation to make it process driven on the lines of Exxon and Shell. Sources add that RIL is likely to finalise a USD 5 billion plan at Jamnagar in 2011 which includes new cracker and downstream expansion. The decision on building LNG terminal may be taken in 2011. However, it may not be in Jamnagar.  Further RIL has revived talks with BP to sell stake in exploration and production (E&amp;amp;P) assets.  &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;
